com.xhive.index.interfaces
Interface XhiveIndexListIf

public interface XhiveIndexListIf

The XhiveIndexListIf stores all XhiveIndexIf objects. Use XhiveLibraryChildIf.getIndexList() to obtain the indexlist.

Tables:

  • Index scope
    •
  • Live behaviour and internal usage
    •

Topics:

  • Index options
    • Sorted keys

    • Full text indexes
    •
  • Default indexes
    •
  • Index performance
    •

Index Scope
An indexlist can be owned by a document or a library.

Databases, libraries and documents support different types of indexes. The table below shows the supported index types by object type:

Index type XhiveLibraryIf XhiveDocumentIf
Context conditioned Index yes yes
Library name Index yes no
Library id Index yes no
Id attribute Index yes yes
Value Index yes yes
Element name Index (*) yes yes
Selected element name Index yes yes
Full Text Index yes yes

Live behaviour and internal usage
The following table shows which index types have live behaviour and how they are used internally. Live indexes are updated automatically when data is updated:

Index type Live BehaviourUsed by
Context conditioned Index no No internal usage
Library name Index yes Full path XPointer, XhiveLibraryIf.get(name)
Library id Index yes Full text indexing, , XhiveLibraryIf.get(id)
Id attribute Index yes XQuery, XPath, XPointer, DOM functions
Value Index yes XQuery
Element name Index (*) yes XQuery, XPath, XPointer, DOM functions
Selected element name Index yes XQuery, XPath, XPointer, DOM functions
Full Text Index yes XQuery

(*) Element name indexes replace the optimized libraries of X-Hive/DB version 2.0 and earlier.

Index options
An index can be created with the following options:

  • Sorted keys In order to use range queries, the index must have sorted keys.
    The update performance of indexes without sorted keys may be better than the performance of indexes with sorted keys.
    Use option XhiveIndexIf.KEY_SORTED to keep the keys sorted.

  • Index type options

    A value index has a type. When creating a value index, you can specify the type with one of the XhiveIndexIf.TYPE_* constants. The default type is XhiveIndexIf.TYPE_STRING. The index type determines what queries can use the index.

Index types X-Hive/DB supports the follwing live indexes:

  • Value indexes
    Value indexes store elements by their element- or attribute- value. X-Hive/DB supports the following value indexes:
    • Indexing elements of name by element value. The element value is stored as key. Create this index by setting element parameters.
    • Indexing elements containing an attribute of name. The attribute value is stored as key. Create this index by setting attribute parameters.
    • Indexing elements of name containing an attribute of name. The attribute value is stored as key. Create this index by setting element and attribute parameters.

  • Full text indexes Full text indexes are quite similair to value indexes since they also store elements by their element- or attribute- value. The key difference however is that in case of the full text index the element or attribute value is tokenized into a number of terms, and each term/element combination is added to the index. Full text indexes are much larger than normal value index but also allow more flexible searching (searching on terms instead of a complete element value).

    The tokenization process is controlled by the analyzer. The default analyzer starts a new token when it encouters a charachter that is neither a letter nor a digit.

    Full text indexes are only used by XQuery when using the full text search function xhive:fts(...). For example, after you have put a full text index on a 'title' element, you can use XQueries like: 

     //title[xhive:fts(., 'regulations OR assembly')]
 //title[xhive:fts(., 'reg*s AND assembly')]
 //title[xhive:fts(., '"The Trusteeship Council shall consist of"')]

  • Id attribute indexes
    An id attribute index stores elements by their element id. An element id is the (unique) attribute of an element of type ID.

  • Element name indexes
    Element name indexes store elements by their node name. The user can choose between a 'general' element name index, where all elements are indexed, and a 'selected' element name index where the user can define a selection of element names to index. In general, only a part of the element names in the documents are used in queries. Although 'general' element name indexes are easy to use as no selection of element names is needed, the price of this type of indexes may be high. Users are recommended to use 'selected' element name indexes instead of the 'general' element name indexes for the following reasons:
    • Disk space Users should be aware that an index size grows proportional to both the number of element names and the number of elements by name stored. As a result, the size of a selected element name index can be a fraction of the size of a general element name index.
    • Index update speed The index update speed is also proportional to the number of element names of the updated data and the number of stored elements by name. The update speed of the index can be greatly enhanced by indexing only a selection of the element names.
    Keys of element name indexes
    Element name indexes store elements by element name. To distinguish between elements of same (local)name with different namespaces, keys must be namespace aware. An element is indexed with key:
    • String nodeName, when the namespaceURI is null
    • String namespaceURI + ' ' + localName, when the namespaceURI is not null. The string contains both namespaceURI and local name, devided by one single space character. I.e. an element with namespaceURI = "http://www.x-hive.com" and local name = "chapter" is indexed by key "http://www.x-hive.com chapter"
      • .

  • Library name indexes
    A library name index stores the XhiveLibraryChildIf nodes by name and optimizes the XhiveLibraryIf.get(String name) and XhiveLibraryIf.setName functions. By default, libraries are created with a library name index. This index is locked with its owner. If the library is expected to store a large number of named documents, this index should be replaced by a library name index with its own locking context.

  • Library id indexes A library id index stores the XhiveLibraryChildIf nodes by name and optimizes the XhiveLibraryIf.get(String name) and XhiveLibraryIf.setName functions. By default, the root library has a library id index.

Default indexes
By default, all libraries have a library name index. Furthermore, the root library also has a library id index. Both indexes are locked with their owner.

Index performance
Indexes are essential to query performance. However, users should add indexes to libraries and documents with care. I.e., the following rules enable a good update and query performance of indexes:

  • Do not add more indexes than required
  • Make the index as selective as possible
  • Use selected element name indexes instead of default element name indexes
These and other issues concerning index performance are discussed in the manual section "Index performance".

(c) X-Hive Corporation B.V. (www.x-hive.com)

Since:
X-Hive/DB 1.0

getIndex

XhiveIndexIf getIndex(java.lang.String name)
Get the XhiveIndexIf interface with the specified name.

Every index in the index list has a unique name.

Returns:
The XhiveIndexIf interface with the specified name.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 1.0

addNodeFilterIndex

XhiveCCIndexIf addNodeFilterIndex(java.lang.String nodeFilter,
                                  java.lang.String name)
Create and add a nodefilter index with the default index options to the index list.

The index has the following default settings:

  • The index has its own locking context.
  • The index does not maintain the keys ordered.

Parameters:
nodeFilter - the class name of the node filter. This node filter both validates and provides the key to an index entry.
name - the name of the new index.
Returns:
An XhiveCCIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
more information about building filters, more information about index scope, more information about live behaviour and internal usage

                                  int options)

The index has the following default settings:

  • The index does not maintain the keys ordered.

name - the name of the new index.
options - a combination of one or more of the following properties of the index: XhiveIndexIf.NO_OPTIONS, XhiveIndexIf.KEY_SORTED.

                           java.lang.String elementURI,
                           java.lang.String elementName,
                           java.lang.String attributeURI,
                           java.lang.String attributeName)
Create and add a value index with the default index options to the index list.

Parameters:
name - the name of the new index.
elementURI - the element uri if namespaces are involved, otherwise null
elementName - the name of the indexed element or null if elements are indexed only by attribute name. Use local name when namespaces are involved, otherwise tagname.
attributeURI - the attribute uri if namespaces are involved, otherwise null
attributeName - the attribute name or null if elements are indexed by element value. Use local name when namespaces are involved, otherwise attribute name
Returns:
An XhiveIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

more information about index scope, more information about live behaviour and internal usage

                           java.lang.String elementURI,
                           java.lang.String elementName,
                           java.lang.String attributeURI,

Parameters:
name - the name of the new index.
elementURI - the element uri if namespaces are involved, otherwise null
elementName - the name of the indexed element or null if elements are indexed only by attribute name. Use local name when namespaces are involved, otherwise tagname.
attributeURI - the attribute uri if namespaces are involved, otherwise null
attributeName - the attribute name or null if elements are indexed by element value. Use local name when namespaces are involved, otherwise attribute name
options - a combination of one or more of the following properties of the index: XhiveIndexIf.NO_OPTIONS, XhiveIndexIf.KEY_SORTED and one of the XhiveIndexIf.TYPE_* options.

An XhiveIndexIf object.

addFullTextIndex

XhiveIndexIf addFullTextIndex(java.lang.String name,
                              java.lang.String elementURI,
                              java.lang.String elementName,
                              java.lang.String attributeURI,
                              java.lang.String attributeName,
                              java.lang.String analyzerClassName,
                              int options)
Create and add a full text index with the specified index options to the index list.

Parameters:
name - The name of the new index.
elementURI - The element uri if namespaces are involved, otherwise null
elementName - the name of the indexed element or null if elements are indexed only by attribute name. Use local name when namespaces are involved, otherwise tagname.
attributeURI - The attribute uri if namespaces are involved, otherwise null
attributeName - The attribute name or null if elements are indexed by element value. Use local name when namespaces are involved, otherwise attribute name
analyzerClassName - The name of the analyzer class to use. If null the default analyzer is used.
options - A combination of one or more of the following properties of the index: XhiveIndexIf.NO_OPTIONS, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_SUPPORT_PHRASES, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_SA_ADJUST_TO_LOWERCASE, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_SA_FILTER_ENGLISH_STOP_WORDS, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_GET_ALL_TEXT. Note that full text indexes are always created with sorted keys.
Returns:
An XhiveIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 4.0
See Also:
more information about index scope, more information about live behaviour and internal usage

addElementNameIndex

XhiveIndexIf addElementNameIndex(java.lang.String name)
Create and add an element name index with the default index options to the index list.

As selected element names indexes only index elements of a selection of element names, the update performance of these indexes can be much better than element name indexes.

The index has the following default settings:

  • The index has its own locking context.
  • The index does not maintain the keys ordered.

Parameters:
name - the name of the new index.
Returns:
An XhiveIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 3.0
See Also:
more information about the keys of element name indexes, more information about selected element names indexes, more information about index scope, more information about live behaviour and internal usage

addLibraryNameIndex

XhiveIndexIf addLibraryNameIndex(java.lang.String name)
Create and add a library name index with the default index options to the index list.

The index has the following default settings:

  • The index is locked with its owner.
  • The index does not maintain the keys ordered.

A library name index can only be created on library level. Use XhiveLibraryIf.getIndexList() to obtain the indexlist.

By default, libraries are created with a library name index

Parameters:
name - the name of the new index.
Returns:
An XhiveIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
more information about index scope, more information about live behaviour and internal usage

addMetadataValueIndex

XhiveIndexIf addMetadataValueIndex(java.lang.String name,
                                   java.lang.String keyName,
                                   int options)
Create and add an index on library child metadata. The index key is the complete value of the metadata entry. If that value is null, the entry is not indexed.

Parameters:
name - The name of the new index.
keyName - The key of the metadata to index. If this is null, all metadata entries will be indexed.
options - A combination of one or more of the following properties of the index: XhiveIndexIf.NO_OPTIONS, XhiveIndexIf.KEY_SORTED.
Returns:
An XhiveIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.1

addMetadataFullTextIndex

XhiveIndexIf addMetadataFullTextIndex(java.lang.String name,
                                      java.lang.String keyName,
                                      java.lang.String analyzerClassName,
                                      int options)
Create and add a full text index on library child metadata. The index keys are the separate words of the value of the metadata entry, as determined by the analyzer.

Parameters:
name - The name of the new index.
keyName - The key of the metadata to index. If this is null, all metadata entries will be indexed.
analyzerClassName - The name of the analyzer class to use. If null the default analyzer is used.
options - A combination of one or more of the following properties of the index: XhiveIndexIf.NO_OPTIONS, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_SUPPORT_PHRASES, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_SA_ADJUST_TO_LOWERCASE, XhiveIndexIf.FTI_SA_FILTER_ENGLISH_STOP_WORDS. Note that full text indexes are always created with sorted keys.
Returns:
An XhiveIndexIf object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.1

addPathValueIndex

XhiveIndexIf addPathValueIndex(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String path,
                               int options)
Create a value index on elements with the specified path. See the manual for a description of the path format.

Parameters:
name - The name of the new index.
path - The path to the elements to be indexed.
options - a combination of one or more of the following properties of the index: XhiveIndexIf.NO_OPTIONS, XhiveIndexIf.KEY_SORTED, XhiveIndexIf.UNIQUE_KEYS, XhiveIndexIf.CONCURRENT.
Returns:
The new index.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0
